description: From Middle English lollen, lullen (“to lounge idly, hang loosely”), of uncertain origin; the Middle English Dictionary suggests a derivation from Middle Dutch lollen, lullen (“to doze; to mumble, talk nonsense”), though the words could merely be cognate. Compare modern Dutch lol (“fun”)), Icelandic lolla (“to act lazily”). See also lull.

verbs.description: loll (third-person singular simple present lolls, present participle lolling, simple past and past participle lolled)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To act lazily or indolently while reclining; to lean; to lie at ease. [from mid-14th c.]
examples: And think'ſt thou, Jove himſelf, with Patience then / Can hear a Pray'r condemn'd by wicked Men? / That, void of Care, he lolls ſupine in State, / And leaves his Bus'neſs to be done by Fate?

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To hang extended from the mouth, like the tongue of an animal heated from exertion. [from 1610s]
(transitive, intransitive) To let (the tongue) hang from the mouth in this way.
examples: The ox stood lolling in the furrow.
